Any support or prayers are greatly appreciated. It is stressful for the communities and members. The KFN leadership made arrangements for most members to stay in one hotel. The crisis seems to be bringing our Dene traditional values of socializing back to life. 

All the challenges we face in our community is still evident. But living together in such close proximities seems to be having a positive impact.  We are responding with love, kindness, respect and care. 

When you pray you humble yourself before God. This humility will come alive when interacting in your community. You will make a difference, so keep praying.

Hello everyone,

I hope everyone is getting to a safe spot in your travels. I'm a news reporter for News North trying to help fill in for our Yellowknife newsroom during the evacuation. Iâ€™m not a person to normally rant on this platform but after being evacuated for the 3rd time in 2 years I just cannot help but speak out. 

This EIDS relief payment is not a fair payment relief for those of us that work hard for our money and have awesome companies that keep us employed and paid during an evacuation (then again I may not be getting paid who knows till you get back to work ). But if I was not evacuated I would have my money in my bank account not using it for hotel bills beyond my control due to evacuation. Everyone should be treated with the same assistance. While I see seniors (and not just seniors) here in high level paying out of pocket  because they cannot physically make the long drives, or sleeping on cots in an arena
This only teaches us to stay in a dangerous situation and wait to be rescued to get fair treatment.

Before I end my rant. May I just send out a big thank you to every person in the registration centre here in High Level for the respect and comfort shown even when they were not instructed to do so. And all the High level people who have welcomed us into their community. 

Thank you all for taking the time to read my post hopefully the GNWT politicians will take a moment and read it as well.

As told by the Alberta representative, the airport process will be the same when flying in and there are Alberta Representative desk set up upon arrival. They are open 8am to midnight. âš ï¸ Wood Buffalo Complex (previously Parks Canada Fire 7, Alberta Wildfire MNZ003, and NWT SS069)

As of yesterday evening, the Government of Northwest Territories, Parks Canada, and Alberta Wildfire have made the decision to enter Unified Command. Unified Command means that there is shared responsibility of command among all agency Incident Commanders. 

This decision was made because there was originally a wildfire in Wood Buffalo National Park that has now breached the Northwest Territories and Alberta borders. Once a wildfire crosses jurisdictional boundaries, multiple agencies may start working in close quarters and establishing Unified Command will help keep objectives and communications clear. 

This creates a safer environment to work on the wildfire as all agencies know where all resources are working. This also allows for better utilization of resources so that operations can work in tandem, rather than working around each other.

â¡ï¸Wood Buffalo Complex is currently 431,198 hectares in size. It is located approximately 4km south of Fort Smith, NWT and 6km south of Fort Fitzgerald, AB.

â¡ï¸Collectively, there are 163 personnel, 21 helicopters and 29 pieces of heavy equipment responding to the Wood Buffalo Complex today. 

Thanks to the increased humidity and light winds the Wood Buffalo Complex wildfire in Wood Buffalo National Park has had little growth over the past two days. Last night, we received 1mm of precipitation in Fort Smith. 

Todayâ€™s priority continues to be placed on efforts to prevent the fire from impacting Fort Smith, the Fort Smith airport, Fort Fitzgerald, Smithâ€™s Landing First Nation, Thebacha, Bordertown, Halfway and Bell Rock.

A fire guard was established around part of the fire on the east side of Highway 5 near where the Salt River runs under the road. Today, crews are finishing work along the guard to extinguish hot spots, with the help of helicopter bucketing. An old fire guard has been re-established running from west 40 at Highway 5 west of Fort Smith and has now been connected to the airport to aid in community protection. We are also creating a fire guard around Fort Fitzgerald and Smithâ€™s Landing First Nation.

Crews continue to examine opportunities to conduct strategic micro-ignition efforts near Highway 5 to gently bring the fire to the pavement. Removing fuel prior to an approaching fire can slow down the spread of fire once it joins up with the burned area.

Nunavut Tunngavik Inc. Offers Assistance to Nunavut Inuit Affected by Evacuation Orders
(August 17, 2023, Iqaluit, Nunavut) As wildfires continue to threaten communities in the Northwest Territories (NWT) and displace families from their homes, Nunavut Tunngavik Inc. (NTI) is taking measures to extend support to affected Nunavut Inuit households. This vital initiative aims to provide immediate relief to eligible households impacted by evacuation orders, including those in Yellowknife, Ndilo, Dettah, Enterprise, Fort Smith, Hay River, Jean Marie River, and Behchoko.

In response to the urgent need, NTI is introducing relief in the form of a one-time payment of $1,000 per household. This assistance is intended to alleviate the immediate challenges faced by Nunavut Inuit households directly affected by the evacuation orders.

Nunavut Inuit households with established addresses within the impacted communities are automatically approved and should contact NTI to provide direct deposit information. 

In cases where the enrolled address does not match evacuation orders, but the individual resides therein, proof of residency along with direct deposit information should be provided to NTI. Examples of proof of residency include a driverâ€™s licence, utility bill or a lease.

Additionally, NTI recognizes the challenges faced by Inuit communities beyond the Northwest Territories and acknowledges that evacuation orders may have impacted individuals in other parts of Canada. To this end, NTI extends support to any Nunavut Inuit households that have been evacuated due to natural disasters such as wildfires, flooding, and others, regardless of their location in 2023. Nunavut Inuit should submit a copy of the evacuation order, alongside proof of residency and direct deposit information.

Contact NTI by email to relief@tunngavik.com or toll-free phone to 1-888-236-5400. The direct deposit form is available for download on NTIâ€™s website at www.tunngavik.com. Be advised that payments may take 1 to 2 weeks to process.
